_prev_prog_3.Description:
Sun Pacific has prepared a unified Risk & Process Safety Management Program.

The program is in compliance with California's Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP)

Program (in California CCR Title 19, Chapter 4.5 Program Level 3 Elements. At the Federal level, Title 40 CFR Part 68), and California OSHA's "Process Safety Management (PSM) of Acutely Hazardous Materials" standard (in California CCR Title

8, Section 5189, "Process Safety Management of Acutely Hazardous Materials," and Federally Title 29 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) 1910.119). This program has been prepared to address the risks involved with the presence of anhydrous ammonia in an amount in excess of 10,000 lbs., which is contained in our refrigeration system.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary



This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:

California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5

Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR ?68

California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR ?5189

Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR ?1910.119



Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.



This program is intended to be a "living document". As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, Sun Pacific Tulare has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 



1.1 Sun Pacific Tulare, Risk and Process Safety Management Program



This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Sun Pacific Tulare has updated their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following process which has the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 



Process Name                | Process Chemical                | Process Quantity(lbs.)

Ammonia Refrigeration         Anhydrous Ammonia                 30,000



Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses, and physical property damage.



Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. We have: 

1. Prepared a unified program based on the PSM regulation to meet CalARP and RMP

obligations as well

2. Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general business practices

3. Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)



The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures, and practices that will help our employees and neighbors protect themselves.



1.2 Process Description



Facility Layout



Sun Pacific Tulare operates a commercial cold storage for a variety of fruits in Tulare, CA. The facility has an ammonia refrigeration system that provides refrigeration capacity to the following:

 

(10) CA Storage Rooms

(3) Cold Storage Rooms

(2) Precool Rooms

(2) Hallways

(1) Loading Dock/Staging Area

(1) Hydrocooler Area



Refrigeration System Equipment

The refrigerated spaces are equipped with air-cooling evaporators and accumulators, and the hydrocooler is equipped with air-cooling evaporators (bare coils) and two (2) accumulators as required for flooded operation.

 

Most control valve groups are located in the center hall (catwalk) to provide easy access. The refrigeration machinery is contained within or directly above the machinery room. A partial list of system components includes:



Machinery Room

(6) Screw compressors

(5) Oil separators

(1) High pressure receiver

(1) Liquid transfer unit

(1) Main suction accumulator

 

Condenser Area

(3) Evaporative condensers

 

CA Storage 20

(1) Air-cooling evaporator (ceiling-suspended)



CA Storage 21

(1) Air-cooling evaporator (ceiling-suspended)



CA Storage 22

(1) Air-cooling evaporator (ceiling-suspended)



CA Storage 23

(1) Air-cooling evaporator (ceiling-suspended)



CA Storage 24

(1) Air-cooling evaporator (ceiling-suspended)



CA Storage 25

(1) Air-cooling evaporator (ceiling-suspended)



CA Storage 26

(1) Air-cooling evaporator (ceiling-suspended)



CA Storage 27

CA Storage 28

(1) Air-cooling evaporator (ceiling-su

spended)

Hydrocooler Area

Process Chemistry



The refrigeration system employed at Sun Pacific Tulare is a flooded system. In this system, high pressure liquid from the high pressure receiver is piped to multiple accumulators. Each accumulator is equipped with an expansion valve which expands the high pressure liquid into a low temperature and pressure liquid as it enters the accumulator. Each accumulator either feeds one ceiling suspended evaporator coil located in the CA Storage Rooms, or four bunker mounted evaporator coils located in the Cold Storage/Precooler Rooms. The evaporators contain a set of continuous coils through which the low pressure liquid flows. Due to the low pressures and temperatures maintained in the evaporator, the liquid refrigerant absorbs a great deal of heat from the surrounding area and evaporates. To increase the rate of heat removed, the evaporator uses an electric fan to move warm air over the coils of cold liquid ammonia. Once the liquid has evaporated to form low temperature and pressure vapor, it travels back to the accumulators, through a suction return line, and into the main suction accumulator. Any rema

ining liquid falls to the bottom of the vessel and is fed by gravity into the transfer vessel. Inside the transfer vessel, the liquid rises in temperature and is returned to the high pressure receiver as high pressure liquid. From the main suction accumulator, the remaining low pressure vapor is piped to the suction inlet on the screw compressors.



The system also includes direct expansion (DX) ceiling suspended evaporator coils. In DX evaporators, high pressure liquid is supplied from the high pressure receiver directly to the evaporators. Each evaporator is equipped with an expansion valve which reduces the pressure and temperature of the liquid as it enters the evaporators. Once the liquid has evaporated to form low temperature and pressure vapor, it exits the evaporators and is returned to the main suction accumulator.



The compressors compress the low pressure vapor, and it exits through the discharge outlet as a high pressure and high temperature vapor. The vapor is then sent to the evaporative condensers where it is cooled and liquefied. The condenser uses air and water to cool the warm ammonia as it passes through a series of tubes within the condenser. As the cooling medium of air and water draws the heat from the vapor, the refrigerant condenses into a liquid and flows to the high pressure receiver. The receiver serves as a holding tank for the liquid refrigerant being fed to the low side, and holds the bulk of the refrigerant in the system when it is not operating. 



Safety Systems 



The machinery room is equipped with a roof-mounted emergency ventilation fan that runs continuously across the line.



Each screw compressor has numerous safety devices to protect the compressor and the associated equipment.



All ASME pressure vessels and positive displacement compressors are equipped with pressure relief valves designed to relieve pressure and protect the equipment from rupturing. The relief valves on the high side relieve at 250 or 300 psig while

the low side relieves at 150 psig. All pressure relief valves are piped to atmosphere.



The main suction accumulator is equipped with a high level float switch that is wired to shut down the compressors in the event of a high level situation. This prevents liquid ammonia from 

entering the compressor.



The emergency pressure control system was installed in accordance with ANSI/IIAR 2-2014.



The Emergency Pressure Control System (EPCS) operates as follows: 

EPCS is activated at not greater than 90% pressure relief valve setting (e.g. 270 psig or less) [ANSI/IIAR 2-2014 Appendix I.4.5.3] 

Upon activation, all compressors are stopped by a means that is independent of all other safety controls [ANSI/IIAR 2-2014 Appendix I.4.5.6] 

Upon activation, cross-over valve is opened [ANSI/IIAR 2-2014 Appendix I.4.5.6] 

Upon activation, a signal is provided to personnel responsible for refrigeration system maintenance [ANSI/IIAR 2-2014 Appendix I.4.5.7] 

EPCS remains active until manually reset [ANSI/IIAR 2-2014 Appendix I.4.5.8]

EPCS crossover isolation valves are locked open [ANSI/IIAR 2-2014 Appendix I.4.4.2] 



The emergency pressure control system is seldom used in a refrigeration system, but has been installed for rare emergency situations.



Process Classification



The ammonia refrigeration system at Sun Pacific Tulare consists of vessels, equipment, and valves which are interconnected by piping. As such, the refrigeration system at Sun Pacific Tulare is treated as a single process.



1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps



1.3.1 General 



We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meeting we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.



Sun Pacific Tulare has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the a

mmonia refrigeration process. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders. 



1.3.2 Anhydrous Ammonia



The ammonia refrigeration process at the Sun Pacific Tulare facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.



Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep active records of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the process is checked frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment. 



1.4 Five Year Accident History



Sun Pacific Tulare has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.



1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan



Sun Pacific Tulare's emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:

Cal/OSHA's Emergency Action Plan - Title 8 CCR ?3220

U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Emergency Action Plans - Title 29 CFR ?1910.38

Cal/OSHA's Process Safety Management [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 8 CCR ?5189(n)

U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Process Safety Management [Emergency Planning and Response Requirements] - Title 29 CFR ?1910.119(n)

California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4.5 ?2765.1-2765.2

USEPA Risk Management Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 40 CFR ?68.95

California Hazardous Materials Business Plan (HMBP) [Emergency Response Pl

ans and Procedures] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4 ?2731

California "Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response" (HAZWOPER) - Title 8 CCR Title 8 ?5192(q)

Federal "Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response" (HAZWOPER) - Title 29 CFR ?1910.120(q)



Strategically, we will respond "minimally" to a release. Under this plan we will call emergency personnel and evacuate the facility. All response activities would be done in coordination with the Local Fire Department and their Hazardous Materials Response Team. 



Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.



1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Sun Pacific Tulare has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, Sun Pacific Tulare continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.



By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved Sun Pacific Tulare's ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that Sun Pacific Tulare's management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.

Sun Pacific Tulare has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.



In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, Sun Pacific Tulare has also entered into a contract wi

th Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation.



For the future, Sun Pacific Tulare now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a "living document". It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for Sun Pacific Tulare employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program Sun Pacific Tulare will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.
